Award.AwardTitle: Exploring response properties of molecules and extended systems using theoretical methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jochen Autschbach of the University at Buffalo, State University of New York, and his research team are developing and applying theoretical models to describe how molecules interact with light. Professor Autschbach is investigating how molecules interact simultaneously with magnetic fields and electromagnetic radiation. This phenomenon occurs in a chemical measurement technique called nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), which is related to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) used in modern medicine. He is also studying how molecules and their mirror-image counterparts interact with light and how the environment around a molecule influences its interaction with light. Such properties are frequently measured in order to deduce information about the structures and functions of molecules, and theoretical support is needed to help establish these relationships. Professor Autschbach is making available the theoretical methods and software developed during this investigation to the larger community of scientists. This research project provides an in-depth training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as an opportunity for high school students to experience a summer internship. The graduate and undergraduate student experience is being enhanced by the collaborative nature of the project, because the project is being carried out in collaboration with experimentalists from a variety of fields, including materials science and catalysis

Quantum-theoretical methods are being developed to understand how molecular structure and dynamics influence a variety of molecular optical and spectroscopic properties. Such properties are frequently measured in order to deduce information about the structures and functions of molecules, and theoretical support is needed to help establish these relationships. Specifically, the parameters being addressed in this project include determining the NMR response and the optical activity of molecules. The calculations focus on NMR relaxation phenomena and on the structural and electronic origins of natural electronic and vibrational optical activity. In addition, the influence of the chemical and physical environment on these molecular properties is being explored.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project we use high-performance computing and quantum theory to calculate how molecules and nano-scale systems interact with light or electric and magnetic fields. The project also requires computational predictions of how molecules react with each other. The calculations tell us how the electrons in a molecule respond to the presence of light and other types of fields, which is why the word 'response' appears in the project title. The interactions of the molecules with the light or fields underpin science's most powerful experimental tools for revealing the chemical bonding in molecules, their geometric shapes, and how the bonding and molecular shapes change during chemical reactions.

The intellectual merit of the research project is the prediction of molecular interactions with electromagnetic fields for important types of molecules for which the arrangements of atoms and chemical bonds are not known, or contested, but need to be known urgently. Another facet of the research is explaining experimental observations, in order to confirm that they are properly understood and interpreted. A third aspect is to develop a better fundamental understanding of molecule - field interactions, i.e. what makes them strong or weak, or why does an observed effect have a certain sign and not the other. A fourth aspect is building confidence in the theoretical calculations to the point that reliable predictions of new physico-chemical phenomena can be made.

Molecular systems that have been studied with support from this grant are catalysts and industrial co-catalysts whose structures and reactivity are often poorly understood. It would have tremendous economic impact if these catalyst systems could be improved in a rational design process. We also very active researching the optical properties of molecules that contain groups with helical shapes. These molecules come in pairs that are mirror-images of one another, with different optical properties. We speak of these molecules as having a 'handedness', or 'chirality' (from the Greek word for hand, as our left and right hands are mirror images of one another). The pairs can be separated, and they have different 'chiro-optical' properties. Most biologically active molecules are chiral. Potential applications of the helical systems that we are studying are in optical materials that require strong chiro-optical effects.

The project also has made significant progress toward the computational prediction of dynamic phenomena in liquid phase systems that can be probed by an experimental technique called nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), which probes the response of atoms and molecules to magnetic fields. We perform dynamic simulations of liquid systems, such as solutions of sodium chloride in water. The dynamic behavior of the water molecules surrounding the sodium and chloride ions is then reflected in the NMR signals of the ions, specifically in the widths of the observed spectral lines. This part of the project is still in an early stage, in the sense that up to now new theoretical and computational methods have been developed for calculating the line widths. Now, these new computational methods are ready to be applied to systems of broad interest in chemistry.

The broader impacts of the project are as follows: As part of the project, new theoretical methods were developed for calculating interactions between molecules and electromagnetic fields, and to improve the accuracy of such calculations. These are available to other researchers and the public in the free open-source quantum chemistry package NWChem (https://nwchemgit.github.io/) of which the principal investigator (PI) is a co-developer, and in other quantum chemistry software packages. Our developments of new theoretical methods contribute to the scientific software infrastructure in general and are used by chemists, bio-chemists, physicists, and material scientists. Some of our research has implications for bio-medical research, catalysis, and materials research. In-depth training in science, technology, engineering, and mathematical (STEM) fields is widely recognized as a crucial asset for any advanced nation in the 21st century. Crucial parts of the training of a research scientist are 'hands-on', by observing and interacting with experienced researchers. The PI and his group contribute actively to this endeavor, by training next generation scientists in the laboratory and by providing research experiences for undergraduate students. Furthermore, the PI's outreach and his numerous contributions to the chemical education literature help to train the next generation of scientists as well as school teachers who educate our children.

During the period of this grant, the PI completed a quantum theory textbook for beginners as well as more experienced students and researchers. (Publication is scheduled for late Fall 2020.) The book features several chapters that are strongly influenced by the research carried out under this grant and its predecessors.
